documents.title: that 's it for today !
text: thanks to everyone who posted questions , and to stephen for kindly answering so many of them .
until next time !
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 2:03pm these questions were better than i 'm normally asked .
thanks and goodbye !
wmffra asks : the hit was the best british film i 'd seen up to that point , thanks stephen , of which of your film are you proudest ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 2:02pm i 'm still surprised by the films i 've made .
llivracnhoj asks : hi .
in the mainstream ( and at the oscars ) , the grifters was somewhat overlooked at the time , but is now universally acknowledged as a neo-noir classic .
was it in the script , or was it improvised , to change the chicken sandwich ( from the book ) to a bad trip , when the cop approaches roy when he 's puking up beside his car ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 2:02pm i ca n't answer your specific question .
donald westlake , who knew a lot about thrillers , about this kind of genre , guided me through it .
larringtonlobster asks : is it true that my beautiful launderette was originally pitched as a dot cotton and ethel spinoff ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 2:01pm i 'll ask hanif !
i think we might predate eastenders , i do n't know
laurenceburns asks : what primary qualities draw you to a screenplay ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 2:00pm have n't a clue and do n't want to know .
peadar76 asks : how difficult is it to make a film like the program , given that the cycling world is still reelin ' from the fallout of the lance armstrong saga ?
pun not intended .
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 2:00pm the cycling world were always very supportive .
the tour let us use their archive , i never had any trouble with the cycling world .
we had a good introduction because david walsh and david miller were both cyclists , and were both with us .
cyclists all find it quite funny now , but they say it was a very bad time back then - they laugh about it a lot now .

id9311511 asks : you 've worked with some of the most established writing talent in the industry , your films almost read like a who 's who of writers are you interested in working with brand new writers who are just coming up ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:58pm if they 're good as hanif kureishi , or peter morgan , of course .
verena sixt asks : thank you for wonderful film-going memories over the years .

i particularly recall seeing mr jolly lives next door at a montreal film festival in the late 80s and laughing hysterically with my mum after watching it , while another film goer reacted crossly to the fantastic combination of humour and violence in the film .
his reaction simply fueled our laughter stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:58pm i always liked rik mayall and adrian edmondson , and i remember peter cook being good .
i would never dare make a comedy though - people who do are very courageous .
people either laugh or they do n't - it 's very frightening .
but i hope my films do have good jokes in them .
james o'connell asks : i 'm a music composer for tv adverts and would like to branch into composing for film .
i 've composed for a number of short films .
what would your advice be to someone in my position ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:56pm god knows .
i 've no idea .
be lucky .
it 's very rough world - good luck .
returnmyjedi asks : what is the most beautiful launderette you 've ever been in ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:55pm i 've led a sheltered life .
mrmitchell78 asks : was it difficult to direct steve coogan in philomena , as he had co-written the screenplay and may have had more visual input than an actor just coming into the role ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:54pm no , he 's an intelligent bloke .

quentinoatmeal888 asks : dear mr frears , like your film my beautiful laundrette , are you pleased & rejoice to hear the news today that the populace of great britain as embraced the free market ethos you champion in said film and unemployment is the lowest ever recorded ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:53pm i think it was more complicated about entrepreneurialism than you imply - you sound like charles moore !
the biographer of mrs thatcher .
there 's a new book in which he attacks laundrette as anti-thatcher propaganda , and it is , but not in the way that he describes .
it 's a film with a lot of irony .
did mrs thatcher really support drug dealers ?
vikingbones followed : and what is your view on the increased numbers of people claiming jobseekers allowance ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:54pm i do n't think you 're right .
do you mean young people out of college and school ?
biffers asks : hi stephen , thanks for doing this .
love your work , particularly the hit and dangerous liaisons .
do you subscribe to the auteur theory ?
do you think screenwriters get a rough deal in the movie industry ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:51pm i do n't think writers get a rough deal from me , though often the rougher you treat them , the better it is for them .
do you know what the auteur theory really is ?
because the word is so misused nowadays .

the word was coined by truffaut to describe the work of people who worked in factories , ie the studios , like hitchcock , or ford , and yet their work retained very familiar characteristics of style or theme .
is that what you mean ?
it 's now used to mean artist , and i would n't describe myself as that .
vikingbones asks : i have always wanted to combine a launderette with an internet cafe and call it a laundernet .
i planned to site them near universities and colleges .
do you think it 's viable ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:50pm not a clue !
it 's your money .
possetpot asks : is there a particular filmmaker that you admire and is there any scene in a film that you have referenced in one of your films ?

stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:48pm i particularly admire jacques audiard at the moment , but the whole time i 'm stealing from films - whether it 's theft or homage , i 'm never quite sure , but i like to steal from the best .
in the program , there 's a scene from raging bull - when he talks to himself in the mirror .
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:49pm when i filmed the fight in my beautiful laundrette , i watched on the waterfront in the morning .
asifb asks : what was your reaction on first reading philomena 's script and what did you bring to the story and actors ?
( i think its a perfect film for the story it tells ) .
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:46pm i was obviously interested , and then i think they went through a couple of drafts before i would agree to make it .
when i first read it , there was a scene in which philomena and martin come back from the airport after she 's decided not to come back to england .
they come back to the hotel , but there 's now only one bedroom available , and have to spend the night in the same bed .
i gave steve and jeff a copy of it happened one night .
somehow the scene got cut , but i honestly ca n't remember why !
rghunt57 asks : can you twist someone 's arm at criterion and get sammy and rose get laid released ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:45pm if you tell me whose arm to twist !
i do n't know what i think about that film the problem is that you make a film like laundrette in a golden carefree moment , and then you want to recreate it .
you sometimes make films for sentimental reasons , and it always comes back to bite you in the bum .
i was principally trying to recapture the magic of my beautiful laundrette - i 'm so dominated by that memory i have no other .
the queen was a sequel to the deal - that 's the only time it 's worked for me .
i 've been caught in that trap of sentimentality four times , and only with the queen did i get out of it .
hooplehead asks : what was it like working with martin scorsese on the grifters , and what did you learn from him ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:43pm i ca n't be specific .
i felt very confident that he would guide me through the american system .
i remember towards the end , you go into what in hollywood they call turnaround hell , and they start late in the morning and work late into the night .
if you worked to 7.30 one night , so you could n't start until 10am the next day .
i said why do we have to do this ?
angelica said : they 're trying to screw us .

she had some sort of folk memory of the studio , presumably at her father 's knee , that they try and screw you and were trying to steal something from us whereas all i wanted to do was get back to normal british working hours .
martin explained why they did it .
they were archaic practices - hollywood is a very complicated society .
you had to deal with all that .
it was a kind of paranoia , and angelica would have learned it from her father .
exfi asks : 1 .
why do n't you remake mary reilly with audrey tautou in the title role , chiwetel ejiofor as jekyll and sergi lpez as hyde ?
sadly , we have only seen five of your films .
we really liked dirty pretty things , the grifters , prick up your ears and dangerous liaisons but detested one of the other ones .
can you guess which one we detested ?
how much would you pay to see caroline lucas dropkicking julia roberts in the ring ?
while researching these questions , i read you worked as assistant to karel reisz , lindsay anderson and albert finney .
very nicely done , sir !
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:39pm 1 .
i ca n't imagine why not.2 .
i give up .
but i 'm guessing the queen .
there 's a lot of liberal bias to the ones they like .
it was like having a kind of golden apprenticeship with those three .
karel and lindsay were wonderful men , and albert had to be taught how to make a film , full stop .
i sat in on the lessons .
boavisteiro asks : how did you choose the soundtrack songs for high fidelity ?
were they in the script ?
did nick hornby have a big say ?
did you have a big say ?
were they chosen by committee ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:36pm i suppose a sort of committee .
luckily because i 'm so old , i removed myself from the committee and set myself up as a hanging judge , and they had to convince me the music was good for the film .
young people know everything about music , so i did n't try to compete .
i loved an elvis costello song , shipbuilding , and the lou reed song , which i think is here comes the sun , which seems aty of lou reed .
tom steadman asks : what , if any , habits do you have that help you get through the first few days/weeks of directing a film ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:35pm when i try to sleep , i have quite a lot of stamina .
but most of the time , you 're just trying to understand the film you 're making .
basically you 're trying to get your head clear , and if you 're lucky , you do .
all i really know is that some of these films have been very popular , do n't ask me why .
davemitch1965 asks : what is your favourite film as director , and what is your favourite film of all time ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:33pm if i answer that question i 'll change my mind in five minutes !
i used to say i particularly liked the snapper , from the second book of roddy doyle 's trilogy , but i could easily undermine what i 've just said .
ross care asks : first of all , i love your unique films .
were there any special problems in dealing with relatively contemporary ( and controversial ) events and characters in prick up your ears ?
how closely did you work with elmer bernstein in developing the unusual score for the grifters ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:32pm i do n't remember anything problematic .
very closely , as closely as was needed - it 's a wonderful score .
when i first met alexandre desplat , the great french composer , he hummed it .

documents.title: on jeremy corbyn : 'i think the chaos he 's caused is absolutely wonderful . all you can do is hope '
text: danashcroft asks : you directed the 1997 labour party general election broadcast ( featuring pete postelwaite in a homage to it 's a wonderful life ) .
i wonder what you think of jeremy corbyn as labour leader ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:30pm i think the chaos he 's caused is absolutely wonderful .
all you can do is hope .
sjoukje asks : have you ever turned down a project which in hindsight wished you had n't ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:30pm i was offered thelma and louise .
but i was n't available .
my then agent said that it was nothing much .
i do n't think i would have done it as well as ridley though .

documents.title: his advice for aspiring directors : 'make films and edit them . nothing else matters '
text: liam quane asks : do you have any directorial advice ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:29pm make films and edit them .
nothing else matters .

documents.title: 'it all got a lot easier for me after i had children '
text: liam quane asks : do you have any advice on set control ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:28pm carry a gun it all got a lot easier for me after i had children .
it 's incredibly important .
control is n't quite the right word , but you are making a film in the middle of 100 people , and you have to deal with them .
many of them are extremely clever , and it makes things more interesting - treating them like cattle is an idiotic way to do it .
the other people on the floor are rather interesting and they know just as much as i do .
i ca n't bear it when there 's a lot of shouting .
marthacostello asks : i saw the commentary you and peter morgan did for the queen recently , and you pointed out something i never would 've caught in a million years .
you said that in the scene where charles looks at diana 's coffin for the first time , you cut the sound , so it 's completely silent .
i absolutely love that , so i wondered : are there any other little unexpected things like that that you think can really add to a scene ?
do you have any favorite examples from your own work ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:26pm was n't it shot through a glass door ?
i guess it was more interesting left to the imagination of the audience .
you do things like that all the time , they 're quite ad hoc and off the cuff .

documents.title: on meryl streep : `` wait till you hear her sing ``
text: milena gummer asks : first i want to say that i 'm really excited for the new movie and i ca n't wait to see it in the cinema .
sure it will be great ! !
my question is about mrs. streep , what was the funniest situation on set with her ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:25pm wait til you hear her sing it 's too early to talk about it , i 'm here to talk about the program , so do n't embarrass me !
firstworlder asks : gumshoe was ace .
why the long gap between it ( 1971 ) and your next theatrically released film , the hit ( 1984 , also ace , and i appreciate you were n't exactly idle in the interim ) ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:23pm i retrospect i can see i went back to learn my job .
gumshoe was a wonderful script , it probably deserved a more experienced director .
i was very young and very inexperienced , and it was a sort of clash between old-fashioned british cinema , and new people like neville smith and chris menges , and i suppose myself .
i then made a lot of films at the bbc , so i did n't particularly suffer .

firstworlder says : although not particularly graphic , the scene in the grifters , in which angelica huston 's character is burned with a cigar , is one of the most upsetting things i 've witnessed in a cinema ( phantom menace excepted ) .
that was n't a question but please answer it anyway plus , finally , sorry but : john malkovich ?
( i 'll go away now ) stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:21pm jim thompson wrote the scene in the book - it 's very like that scene .
in the book it takes place at the beverly hills hotel , but they would n't let us film it there .
yes , it 's horrible , it upsets everybody .
re john malkovich - what 's the problem ?
i 'll come back to you
flexiblerosterer asks : do you enjoy making films as much as you ever have ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:19pm i think so .
they 're really hard work , and have got harder .
i saw one of the producers of my beautiful laundrette recently , and remembered how carefree it was when we made it .
money has become more and more central to filmmaking .
manatcanda asks : you cast john hurt as a hitman in one of my all time favourite films , the hit .
john hurt is a wonderful actor , but not an obvious choice for such a role .
did you have someone like him in mind when you first saw the script ?
and how much faith did you need to have to cast the young tim roth opposite him ?
( i need n't add that their performance together was wonderful ) .
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:18pm i had absolute faith in john hurt , he 's a wonderful actor .
tim roth had just played a skinhead in a film by alan clark , and i was struck by how good he was .
i do n't know i had anything in mind though .
recently there 's been talk of doing a remake of the hit , but when i thought about it , all i could do was hear the voices of the original actors - we were very lucky in the three actors we got .
dordrecht asks : can you explain why you hid the french part of the story of the program ?
david walsh was not alone in his investigation , he is not the only one to reveal the scandal .
the others were told to give up their rights for free , what they refused ( by the way , i 'm a great fan of your movies ! )
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:15pm these are much more interesting questions than i 'm used to answering !

you 're absolutely right about the french journalist with whom david wrote the first book , la confidential - it 's a matter between david and the french journalist , but i 'm aware of what you 're talking about .

documents.title: 'i choose films as unconsciously as possible '
text: kemster asks : i have enjoyed a number of your the hit , dangerous liaisons and high fidelity in particular , each of which has a very distinctive and singular style .
do you make a conscious decision to make a departure in terms of your previous works style and theme when choosing projects ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:14pm no , it 's unconscious .
i choose films as unconsciously as possible .
i honestly do n't know , and do n't want to know .
i 'm as surprised as anyone else .
i do n't think i 'd ever make a horror film - i 'm too frightened .
of the genre though , rather than the content .

documents.title: on that daniel day-lewis neck-licking scene
text: tomcend asks : i think two of the most erotic , romantic and even politically-charged moments in cinema occurred in my beautiful laundrette : when johnny licks omar 's neck , and the champagne scene in the back of the laundrette as another interracial but heterosexual couple dances in the background .
i think those scenes still carry a thrill .
can you comment on how those scenes evolved and also what qualities you think make movie scenes successful at evoking eroticism ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:12pm i remember daniel day-lewis on the first day of shooting to lick his ear .
dan looked at me as if the devil had just appeared , and then went at it with enormous gusto .
the champagne scene was just in the script - i am supposed to have asked who 's on top .
i do n't know how you do it get two sexy people !
you direct it in a rather covert way .
i remember encouraging annette bening to do a particular thing in the grifters , and she said : do n't be dirty .
and then she did it .
and then discussing with richard eyre the kiss between angelica huston and john cusack .
richard had just done hamlet at the royal court in which jonathan pryce and jill bennett ( playing his mother ) kissed .
we were discussing incestuous kissing - as otherwise i do n't know very much about incest .
patrick ryan asks : i 've just spent the last couple of weeks in a friend 's flat in lima and started looking at some movies i watched your great piece of work dangerous liaisons ( 1988 ) .

it still remains a stunning piece of filmmaking for me that movie is now a classic i was interested in knowing what movies from other directors that have most impressed you okay there 's plenty on your list so just give me a few examples , please thanks and it 's great to see you back with a new movie .
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:06pm i like the same films you like !
right now i 'm finishing a sort of screwball comedy so i 've been watching lots of american comedies from the 30s - most of the time i watch a night at the opera .
liam quane asks : do you think it 's becoming easier for filmmakers in the uk to become successful ?
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:04pm why on earth would you imagine that ?
it 's very , very tough .
you 're in competition with studios who have vast amounts of money , and make the films the world wants to see .
it 's harder now , because there 's less money about .
there is n't a route to success - make a film , if people like it , you 'll be ok .
there is no route that i know of .
clareyesno asks : you 've had a series of really big hits interspersed with a series of really big flops , eg cheri , lay the favourite , mary reilly .
what 's it like when a film you love and have worked hard on does n't resonate with the public ?
why do you think certain films fail at the box office and others succeed critics , production issues , marketing etc ?
and of your films that have n't performed as well as others , which do you think most deserves being seen ?
sorry if this seems insensitive !
i really like your films and am genuinely interested stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:08pm what an infuriatingly interesting question !
some work and some do n't .
you work just as hard on the ones that fail .
i thought tamara drewe would get a bigger audience - it made me laugh .
i do n't know if `` deserve '' comes into it there are films that do n't find large audiences .
it 's just bad luck i 've no explanation .
i just wish they 'd done better .
there 's not much point in moaning .

tixhiidon says : hi stephen , i do n't have a question for you , but i want to thank you for my beautiful launderette , which had a profound effect on me as a gay teenager in a small town in 1980s england .
i found it eye-opening , erotic , and kind of overwhelming .
it moved me intensely .
so thanks .
stephenfrears 14 october 2015 1:03pm thanks very much !
i 'd like to have been a young person seeing it for the first time .

documents.title: post your questions for stephen frears
text: stephen frears is a cornerstone of british film-making .
in the 1980s , he made his name with state of the nation dramas such as my beautiful launderette and prick up your ears .

if those movies dramatised the lives of marginalised outsiders , his 2006 film the queen offered a study of the ultimate insiders focussing on the rattled windsor household in the wake of the death of princess diana .
but frears has also had a distinguished parallel career in hollywood , making glossy , literate dramas such as dangerous liaisons , the grifters and high fidelity .
out this week is the program , charting the downfall of lance armstrong , while next year sees him team with meryl streep for another bio florence foster jenkins .
he is joining us for a live webchat on wednesday 14 october from 1pm bst onwards , where he 'll answer your questions about his life and work .
post them in the comments below , and he 'll take on as many as possible .
